results.title: [The Australian outback]
results.brief_description: On a cattle station 200 miles from Oodnadatta, stockmen are shown preparing for a muster, mustering scrub cattle, branding and droving the cattle to the trucking yards.

results.title: Men in wool
results.creator_credit: Frank Land and Australian Wool Corporation
results.brief_description: Designed to show the importance of wool in the manufacture of men’s clothing, tracking the cycle from the shearing shed to the tailored suit. Illustrates the process of shearing, grading, scouring and carding and explains the range of tests for strength, elasticity and possible imperfections. Finally shows the manufacture of a suit using mass productions and hand tailoring techniques. Photographed by George Heath; narrated by Michael Charlton; edited by Les Wasley; script by John Moyes Junior; sound by Allyn Barnes.

results.title: Wandering Thru' the Centre
results.brief_description:
A travel film through the centre of Australia. Features the Flying Doctor’s Base at Alice Springs, The Devil’s Marble near Wanchop, Darwin beach and harbour and many other tourist delights to be found en route from Alice Springs to Darwin.

Digitising Technician Note: Film contains footage of the making of “The Overlanders” (1946). Noted by Ben Abbott 09/01/2018

results.title: Lifeblood of the city
results.creator_credit: Melbourne and Metropolitan Board of Works
results.brief_description: How Melbourne has always depended on the Yarra for its existence. The expanding city has drawn upon the Yarra and its tributaries, culminating in the development of the head-waters of the Yarra itself. The climax is the building of the Upper Yarra Dam, shown in detail. The film uses old prints to illustrate past development of Melbourne, with emphasis on its water supply. Material filmed at all stages of the ten years of building the Upper Yarra Dam presents a full picture of how a large rock and earth dam is built. Concludes witht he opening of the reservoir by Sir Dallas Brookes (26th November 1957). Commentary by Geoff Raymond.

results.title: [Royal guest XVI Olympiad 1956]
results.brief_description: A historical record of Prince Philip’s visit to Melbourne during the 1956 Olympic Games. Captures his airport arrival; the public lining Melbourne’s streets to greet the Prince; his visit to Government House; a parade on Swanston street showing a glimpse of Melbourne Town Hall; the opening ceremony at Olympic Games; Robert Menzies and Prince Philip arriving at the Olympic stadium; entrance of athletes at the opening ceremony; Ron Clarke’s memorable entrance into the stadium and the lighting of the Olympic flame; footage of Station Pier in Port Melbourne; Philip arriving at St Paul’s cathedral in Melbourne; an extensive tour of the accomodation facilities prepared for the athletes at Olympic Village in Heidelberg; Philip visit a hospital and the Australian Paper Manufacturers mill in Heidelberg; shows footage of various track and field events in the stadium; a ceremony at Melbourne’s Shrine of Rememberance; the departure of Prince Philip.

results.title: The Greatest Art Movement: Transporting Art: the Story of Melbourne's Art Trams
results.creator_credit: Michael Buckley, National Heart Foundation of Australia. Victorian Division and Arts Victoria
results.brief_description: Trams have always been a feature of Melbourne life and they have now been transformed into moving art galleries. Melbourne’s Transporting Art Project involves a new series of decorated trams. Several of the artists discuss their reasons for taking part in the scheme, the themes behind their work and the unusual medium. Artists include Aleks Danko, Philip Faulks, Lin Onus, Terry Matassoni, Jenny Watson and Brett Colquhoun.
results.title_for_label: The Greatest Art Movement: Transporting Art: the Story of Melbourne’s Art Trams

results.title: Buildings and Bushfires-Improving the Chances of Survival
results.creator_credit: University of Melbourne and Television Production Unit
results.brief_description: Bushfires are an inevitable hazard in Australia. The tranquillity of the bush belies its potential to burn fiercely when conditions are suitable. This program shows how bushfires start fires in buildings, how embers, radiation and flame, aided by wind cause ignition and destruction of buildings; that embers are the most important means of ignition; that well-designed buildings have a very good chance of survival; and that such buildings will provide a safer place of refuge for people in bushfires.
results.title_for_label: Buildings and Bushfires-Improving the Chances of Survival
results.creator_credit_for_label: University of Melbourne and Television Production Unit

results.title: Heaven help us!
results.creator_credit: Robert Kingsbury, Frank Bagnall and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: There’s only one thing wrong with telephones: people use them. This film sets out to explain the simple rules of telephone etiquette with special effects and fantasy sequences. Max Meldrum plays an angel, who for some reason is in charge of heaven’s communications systems! Using a shonky business as an example, he explains the do’s and dont’s of good communication over the phone. Produced for the Australian Post Office.
